Details: Both outputs address the same ETL testing domain with core operations (CSV reading, filtering, column renaming, Snowflake loading). However, Agent_2 provides significantly more comprehensive coverage including edge cases (empty files, null handling, performance testing, error scenarios) that Agent_1 lacks. The semantic intent is aligned but Agent_2 demonstrates deeper understanding of testing requirements.

Both follow similar high-level structure (test cases document + pytest script). Agent_2 shows superior organization with proper pytest fixtures (@pytest.fixture), helper functions, and better separation of concerns. Agent_1 uses simpler structure but lacks the sophisticated setup that Agent_2 provides. Test case documentation format differs (numbered list vs table format).

Agent_1 pytest script has valid Python syntax but contains some issues: missing proper imports for etl_job module (line 75), hardcoded file paths without proper test data setup, and simplified mock assertions that may not reflect real testing scenarios. The test structure is functional but lacks robustness.

Agent_2 demonstrates excellent pytest practices with proper fixtures, temporary file handling, and comprehensive error testing. Minor issues include some simplified mock implementations (lines 180, 200) for Snowflake connectivity, but overall structure is production-ready with proper setup/teardown and edge case handling.
Average correctness score reflecting that both outputs are syntactically valid with Agent_2 showing superior implementation practices and more robust error handling.
